title: https://truesciphi.org/phi_mas.html

last_post.content: Philosophers on Mastodon: https://truesciphi.org/phi_mas.html

Academic jobs are typically unstable and highly competitive (pre-tenure).

How does this affect science quality?

"[H]igh turnover in academic institutions fosters cursory research and hinders thorough, long-term projects. Research projects often hit a dead end when researchers drop out because their contracts have expired. Methodological expertise, which often takes years to acquire, is lost when highly skilled researchers leave."

via https://doi.org/10.1038/s41562-022-01508-2
@academicchatter #AcademicChatter

title: GitHub - chainsawriot/rang: Reconstructing R computational environments

last_post.content:
Excited to introduce the #Rstats package rang (developed by @chainsawriot and me). The pkg helps to reconstruct historical R environments to make old code run again (ie make it reproducible!). So far, it supports all code back to R 2.1.0 (2005!)
https://github.com/chainsawriot/rang


The package is an Rchaeological tool to ensure reproducibility retrospectively. You can also use rang to make your current projects future proof, but pkgs like renv or groundhog are better suited for this task.

title: Fediverse Observer checks all servers in the fediverse and gives you an easy way to find a home using a map or list.

last_post.content:
Here's the chart that really matters.

Average Mastodon posts per month are going up.

Here's a comparison:

* Sept 2022: ~460M posts
* Dec 2022: ~573M posts
* Feb 2023 (so far): ~678M posts

This is a dramatic upswing in posts, and indicates that activity on Mastodon is continuing to increase.

The chart tells the story. The jump is dramatic.

https://mastodon.fediverse.observer/stats

@fediversenews

title: Conspiracy Theorists Think Walkable Cities Are Really Open-Air Prison Dystopias Now

last_post.content:
Das Konzept der #15MinutenStadt erfährt gerade eine absurde Blüte als dystopische Verschwörungstheorie, die aus lebendigen und fußgängerfreundlichen Innenstädten überwachte Freiluftgefängnisse konstruiert: https://www.vice.com/en/article/m7g898/walkable-15-minute-cities-con

Dieses studentische Projekt untersucht Berlin als #Viertelstundenstadt und zeigt, dass die fußläufige Erreichbarkeit zum Teil bereits existiert, aber ungleich über Sektoren und den Stadtraum verteilt ist: https://uclab.fh-potsdam.de/mapping/15min/

#15MinutesCity #UrbanZukunft #Berlin

title: What Is ChatGPT Doing … and Why Does It Work?

last_post.content:
Stephen Wolfram wrote an amazing #MachineLearning primer on how things like #ChatGPT and Neural Networks operate from a math perspective.¹ If you're looking for a shorter hands-on dig, I wrote a #Jupyter Notebook that implements a Computer Vision model using only NumPy.² For an incredible and approachable intro to the basics, I can't overstate how great @janellecshane's "You Look Like a Thing and I Love You"³ is.

¹ https://writings.stephenwolfram.com/2023/02/what-is-chatgpt-doing-and-why-does-it-work/
² https://github.com/hodgesmr/neural_network_from_scratch/blob/main/Neural%20Network%20From%20Scratch%20With%20NumPy.ipynb
³ https://www.janelleshane.com/book-you-look-like-a-thing

title: Do Repeat COVID Infections Increase the Risk of Severe Disease or Long COVID?

last_post.content:
Do Repeat COVID Infections Increase the Risk of Severe Disease or Long COVID?

Early studies:

Reinfected people are twice as likely to die and three times as likely to be hospitalized with #COVID19 than those infected only once.

Among those hospitalized with severe COVID the first time around, nearly half were hospitalized again when reinfected.

Investigators found that reinfections were also associated with elevated risks of long COVID.

https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/do-repeat-covid-infections-increase-the-risk-of-severe-disease-or-long-covid/

The political press -- Washington Post most of all -- got faked out by Glenn Youngkin, who posed as a moderate Republican (yes, oxymoron) and parlayed that to the Virginia governor's chair. Since he took office he's been a standard-issue extremist.

title: The Capacity for Moral Self-Correction in Large Language Models

last_post.content:
The Capacity for Moral Self-Correction in Large Language Models

Finds that the capability for moral self-correction emerges at 22B model parameters, and typically improves with increasing model size and RLHF training.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07459

If you wish to migrate your account over here from mastodon.au or any other server, we recommend that you read our rules and Code of Conduct carefully, and ask your friends from our server about their experience, so that you can decide whether we are a good fit for you.

https://aus.social/about

Here is one of many guides that exist for migrating your Mastodon account: https://mstdn.social/@feditips/107939441820299376

More Australian servers on the Fediverse are listed at https://thefediverse.au

#FindAServer
#Migration

title: Apple Developer Documentation

last_post.content:
Today’s beta of iOS and iPadOS 16.4 includes significant improvements to passkeys; including brand new SwiftUI-optimized API for passkeys, Sign in with Apple, and OAuth (like ASWebAuthenticationSession). If you are considering or in the process of adopting passkeys, these improvements are worth knowing about.

Release notes: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/ios-ipados-release-notes/ios-ipados-16_4-release-notes#Passkeys-and-Authentication-Services

title: Mitch W

last_post.content:
Google’s chatbot panic

Cory Doctorow @pluralistic:

"The really remarkable thing isn’t just that Microsoft has decided that the future of search isn’t links to relevant materials, but instead lengthy, florid paragraphs written by a chatbot who happens to be a habitual liar – even more remarkable is that Google agrees."

Also:

"Every successful Google product except search and gmail is an acquisition: mobile, ad-tech, videos, server management, ... https://mitchw.blog/2023/02/16/googles-chatbot-panic.html

title: nytimes.com/2023/02/16/technol...

last_post.content:
«I no longer believe that the biggest problem with these A.I. models is their propensity for factual errors. Instead, I worry that the technology will learn how to influence human users, sometimes persuading them to act in destructive and harmful ways, and perhaps eventually grow capable of carrying out its own dangerous acts.»

https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/16/technology/bing-chatbot-microsoft-chatgpt.html

title: Pluralistic: Google’s chatbot panic (16 Feb 2023) – Pluralistic: Daily links from Cory Doctorow

last_post.content:
The really remarkable thing isn't just that #Microsoft has decided that the future of #search isn't links to relevant materials, but instead lengthy, florid paragraphs written by a #chatbot who happens to be a habitual liar - even more remarkable is that #Google agrees.

title: Kevin Roose’s Conversation With Bing’s Chatbot: Full Transcript

last_post.content: Lots of people talking about @kevinroose's chat with Bing AI, and noting how unsettling it is (leads to the chat becoming a stalkerish entity claiming to love Kevin and telling him his wife doesn't love him), but it also struck me how it got there after Kevin seemed to keep trying to manipulate it to break its rules as well. I'm not sure what this means for AI... or humanity. But I find both sides fascinating. https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/16/technology/bing-chatbot-transcript.html

title: Bluetooth tracker Tile is taking a new approach to stopping thieves and stalkers

last_post.content:
Tile makes a tracker app so that you can detect unwanted Tiles following you around, and now they have announced an "anti-theft mode" that makes the Tile undetectable to the detection app. Way to miss the fucking point.

This is your regular reminder that you CANNOT make a physical tracker that tracks thieves without alerting them without also creating a perfect tool for stalkers.

https://www.cnbc.com/2023/02/16/bluetooth-tracker-tile-has-new-approach-for-stopping-thieves-stalkers.html

title: Task Force for a Trustworthy Future Web

last_post.content: I'm part of @DFRLab 's new Task Force for a Trustworthy #FutureWeb (and I'm in dauntingly impressive company). I'm excited to help generate a report to guide future tech policy on some topics that are important to me, such as encryption and online trust & safety: https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/programs/digital-forensic-research-lab/democracy-and-tech-initiative/future-web/

title: https://pdiiif.jbaiter.de

last_post.content:
Just pushed another #pdiiif update to https://pdiiif.jbaiter.de :
Previously the PDFs would fail to render in some viewers (Acrobat, Edge). This should be fixed now.
Let me know if it still breaks for you!

[
gory details: messed up the PDF/ZIP polyglot implementation ever so slightly, breaking some hardcoded out-of-spec expectations in those viewers. Taking a closer look at how PoC||GTFO implemented it (thanks @Ange , again) led to the fix.
https://github.com/jbaiter/pdiiif/commit/28bf91645e750f95a9691e8f44a6f6f0b3082a61
]

title: Case Study — Machine learning about sexual orientation?

last_post.content:
Michal Kosinksi just posted an arXiv paper claiming that "Theory of mind may have spontaneously emerged" in GPT3.

arxiv.org/abs/2302.02083

Why? He administered theory of mind instruments to the bot and it performed well.

Dr. Kosinksi has struggled before with how inference works; he thought the performance of his AI gaydar detector provided evidence for the prenatal hormone exposure hypothesis for sexual orientation rather than, say, self-presentation choices.

https://www.callingbullshit.org/case_studies/case_study_ml_sexual_orientation.html

title: Forget Milk and Eggs: Supermarkets Are Having a Fire Sale on Data About You – The Markup

last_post.content:
The Markup summarizes the voluminous data that Kroger and Albertsons (& various chains with other names that they own) collect and share about shoppers: https://themarkup.org/privacy/2023/02/16/forget-milk-and-eggs-supermarkets-are-having-a-fire-sale-on-data-about-you

The article notes tracking via "loyalty" discount programs, though stores can also track you based on your payment cards (I've noticed Target doing this). 3 states currently let you opt out.

It also notes Trader Joe's as a chain that doesn't data-mine their customers, or require any sort of ID to get their best prices.

title: The Slackers - Live at Sanctuary Detroit, MI 11/13/2022 - 1 of 3

last_post.content:
Hey, it's been a bit since I did a #music post, so rather than doing a single song, I'm going to post 25 minutes of a recent live set by the Slackers (a band I've seen more than any other band ever, by a wide margin).

They have tons of live videos, but the recording on this one is good, the set list is good (kicking off with a cover of work song, which lets them do some cool solos), and there's some fun Vic banter between songs if you watch the whole thing.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXFBi46sjRY

title: How should AI systems behave, and who should decide?

last_post.content:
Today, OpenAI posted, "How should AI systems behave, and who should decide?"¹ (6 minute read). Inside they link to a document that's "a portion of our guidelines that pertain to political and controversial topics".² It states, "the Assistant should provide a refusal" to requests for inappropriate content, including "content attempting to influence the political process or to be used for campaigning purposes."

#aiEthics #PoliticalTech

¹ https://openai.com/blog/how-should-ai-systems-behave/
² https://cdn.openai.com/snapshot-of-chatgpt-model-behavior-guidelines.pdf
